title: Severus111
author: Severus111
created_time: January 09, 2025, 10:38:03 AMLast edit: January 09, 2025, 06:11:16 PM by Severus111
content: Does anyone have any information about the owners of Bhex and Hbtc exchange who are both the same people and their possible relationship with other exchanges like Huobi now known as HTX?There seems to be a case where both Bhex/Bluehelix and Hbtc fly by night operations have closed up quickly and taken huge amounts of customers funds with them in what appears to be a case of exit fraud.Who are the actual people behind these exchanges and where are they now?

comments.author: NotATether
comments.body: You're in for a long shot if you think that the identities of the people running those exchanges will somehow be easy to find.These kind of exchanges run with shell companies and front people, so even if you look at official company registrars, you will not see who is the real UBO (Ultimate Beneficial Owner).The thing about these business owner/scammer types is that they are good at covering their tracks unlike small time scammers.

Never tried to take a test to find the identities of such people, however, I would think it would need lots of resources / help from the specialists/people who are good with OSINT too.

comments.author: _act_
comments.body: Quote from: Severus111 on January 09, 2025, 10:38:03 AMWho are the actual people behind these exchanges and where are they now?I have used this exchange before like 3 years ago. But after some time I did not use it again. Some months after, I wanted to login into my account but I was unable to see the exchange on Playstore anymore. I did not make any other findings because I did not have money on the exchange because if I am not using an exchange, I withdraw all my trading money. I did not hear anything about the exchange exit scam. Which means they went away with people's money?

He served as CTO of Huobi Global, VP of Technology in X Financial. During his tenure, X Financial (XYF) was successfully listed on the NYSE. In 2018, He founded BHEX (now rebranded as HBTC Exchange) and received $15 million in angel round financing.How did you call it as an exit scam? have they not allow its users to withdraw the funds before totally going offline?

comments.body: I haven't been able to find much, but there was this individual looking into them last year:https://x.com/efforceaction/status/1725448939581693984Maybe you can try to reach out to him (it seems like he's still active) to see if he has more information on the subject.He also posted this article by Forbes from four years ago that involves the platform you mentioned:https://www.forbes.com/sites/thomassilkjaer/2020/07/06/is-this-3-billion-crypto-ponzi-still-alive/

Yes, James Zhu aka James Wu aka James Ju and probably a few other surnames unknownAlso Tyler Wu ,Chae Hoon& Lee Sangwook the co-founders and joint CEO of Bluehelix Korea Chae Hun/Hoon and Lee Sangwook have worked as Strategic Planning Officer and CFO at Huobi Korea.Quote from: Sanitough on January 09, 2025, 01:25:28 PMHow did you call it as an exit scam? have they not allow its users to withdraw the funds before totally going offline?Not saying it was an exit scam but asking opinions as to whether it was due to people having lost their funds after they simply vanished and possibly set up under a new name and started a "new chain".Coincidently Houbi changed its name to HTX and is a wrapped version of bitcoin called HBTC. On another note Heco chain bridge, the bridge connects the HTX exchange (formerly Huobi) and Ethereum was exploited for approximately $87 million in crypto assets. Large quantities of ETH, USDT and a wrapped version of bitcoin (HBTC) were seen leaving the bridge for a previously unused Ethereum wallet.Also all these exchanges mentioned seem to use the same colour scheme.There are just so many coincidences but this of course proves nothing except the fact many people have lost their money with these people and they seem to have done quite well.Also some people were never contacted to withdraw from HBTC before they disappeared with their money and even if they were and did not meet the timeout there should still be a segregated wallet for those peoples funds.Quote from: OmegaStarScream on January 09, 2025, 01:30:56 PMI haven't been able to find much, but there was this individual looking into them last year:https://x.com/efforceaction/status/1725448939581693984Maybe you can try to reach out to him (it seems like he's still active) to see if he has more information on the subject.Much appreciated, thanks.
